question: What are the criterias in terms of administrative, financial and technical? Are there documents required to be submitted before submission deadline?
answer:
Mentioned  

The tender specifies three groups of criteria and the documents that must be supplied before the submission deadline.

**Administrative criteria** – Candidates must provide a solemn declaration before a competent authority (judicial, notary or professional body) and complete the European Single Procurement Document (ESPD). Confidentiality obligations also apply. [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:17](chunkref://17);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  

**Financial criteria** – The contracting entity will assess economic and financial standing using either official audited annual reports (or excerpts) or relevant bank or accountant statements. [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:17](chunkref://17)  

**Technical criteria** – The quality part of the award (85 %) is evaluated through three sub‑criteria:  
* Organisation (40 %)  
* Qualifications and experience of the personnel (40 %)  
* Technical assistance (20 %)  

These technical sub‑criteria, together with the price criterion (15 %), determine the most economically advantageous tender. [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:17](chunkref://17)  

**Documents that must be submitted before the deadline** – The tender package must include, at a minimum:  
* Completed ESPD (including all required parts) [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  
* Notification of processing of personal data [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  
* Statements on restrictive measures, joint participation and support (as applicable) [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  
* Completed Tender Form Sheet (Appendix 5) [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  
* Description of the tenderer’s project organisation [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  
* CVs of key personnel [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)  

These documents are to be uploaded electronically via Dalux Tender no later than the stated time limit. [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7)

question: What are the required key experts or engineer or personnels to meet the criteria? Is there any language skills requirements of key personnel? (e.g., minimum proficiency levels, required certifications, or project-specific communication capabilities)? Any nationality restrictions? Does Gruner has key experts meeting these criterias?
answer:
Mentioned

The tender specifies that the key experts required are the project manager, electrical‑design manager, mechanical‑design manager, civil‑design manager, quality manager and ICT manager, each with the experience and qualification details listed in the personnel sub‑criterion [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:19](chunkref://19).  

Language skills are also required for the key personnel: at least one person must speak Danish at a minimum C1 level, at least one must speak English at a minimum C1 level, and at least one must speak Greenlandic at a minimum B2 level [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:20](chunkref://20); additionally, English is the language for communications [Particular Conditions_ Part A.pdf, p:2](chunkref://4).  

The documents do not impose any nationality restrictions on the key experts.  

The provided context contains no information about “Gruner” or its staff, so it cannot be determined from the evidence whether Gruner has key experts that satisfy these criteria.

question: Are there any mandatory partnerships (e.g., local firms) required?
answer:
No mention

The procurement documents describe the possibility of participating together with other entities (consortia, joint ventures) and the obligations that apply when a tenderer chooses to do so — such as submitting separate ESPD forms, joint and several liability, and statements of joint participation — but they never state that a partnership with a local firm (or any specific type of partner) is mandatory for eligibility [ref_id:0]; [App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:1](chunkref://1); [App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:1](chunkref://2); [App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:1](chunkref://3). The requirements focus on financial, technical, and professional criteria, not on compulsory local partnerships. Consequently, the provided context does not indicate any mandatory partnership requirement.

question: Are there specific financial stability criteria (e.g., turnover, bank guarantees)?
answer:
Mentioned  

The tender documents set out explicit financial‑stability thresholds that bidders must meet.  
- A minimum average yearly turnover of DKK 40 million for the two preceding financial years is required, together with a solvency ratio of at least 20 % and a liquidity ratio of 100 % in the last financial year [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:13](chunkref://13).  
- Additionally, bidders must disclose their average yearly turnover for the past three financial years, as well as equity, total assets, current assets and current liabilities [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:12](chunkref://12).  

These criteria constitute the financial stability requirements. The documents do not refer to bank guarantees as a condition for financial standing.



When the tenderer participates together with others, cf. Part II.A, or relies on the economic and
financial capacities of other entities, cf. Part II.C, the contracting entity will calculate the total
amounts of the involved entities which must fulfil the minimum requirements (e.g., the

comparable with the tendered Consultancy Service Agreement where the performed services must

agreements is calculated based on the total number from all relevant entities.

‘Description’, the tenderer must specify the performed services, including whether
specific parts were performed by subconsultants engaged by the tenderer,


‘Start date’, the tenderer must state when the consultancy service agreement was
entered into,

‘End date’, the tenderer must state when the consultancy service agreement was
completed, and

‘Recipient’, the tenderer must state the name of the client and contact information for
the client’s project manager or contact person.

The tenderer is encouraged to describe the performed consultancy service agreements with as
much detail as possible and how they are relevant in relation to the minimum requirements below.

The tenderer is required to have performed minimum the following (minimum requirements): 
one consultancy agreement regarding consultancy in connection with construction and

last 10 years, and

one consultancy service agreement regarding consultancy in connection with
construction and civil engineering works in Greenland or in the Arctic (e.g., in Iceland,

and Lappland), Norway (Nordland, Troms, Finnmark, Svalbard and Jan Mayen),

the payment of taxes, both in the country in which the tenderer is established and in
Greenland, or

the payment of social security contributions, both in the country in which the tenderer is
established and in Greenland.

In Part III.C, Grounds relating to insolvency, conflicts of interests or professional misconduct,
the tenderer must answer whether it in the past three years: 
has breached its obligations in the field of environmental law,

has breached its obligations in the field of social law,

has breached its obligations in the field of labour law,

has been bankrupt,

has been the subject of insolvency or winding-up,

has been in arrangements with creditors,

has been in any analogous situation like bankruptcy arising from a similar procedure
under national laws and regulations,

has had assets being administered by a liquidator or by the court,

has suspended its business activities,

has entered into agreements with other participating candidates aimed at distorting
competition,

has been guilty of grave professional misconduct, which renders its integrity
questionable,

is aware of any conflict of interest, as indicated in national law, the relevant notice or
the procurement documents due to its participation in the procurement procedure,

has experienced that a prior public contract, a prior contract with a contracting entity or
a prior concession contract was terminated early, or that damages or other comparable
sanctions were imposed in connection with that prior contract,

has been guilty of serious misrepresentation in supplying the information required for
the verification of the absence of grounds for exclusion or the fulfilment of the selection
criteria, has withheld such information or is not able to submit the required supporting
documents,

has undertaken to unduly influence the decision-making process of the contracting
entity, to obtain confidential information that may confer upon it undue advantages in
the procurement procedure or to negligently provide misleading information that may
have a material influence on decisions concerning exclusion, selection or award.

The tenderer is excluded from the procurement procedure if it is subject to any of the exclusion
grounds above unless it has provided sufficient documentation to the effect that measures taken
by the participating candidate are sufficient to demonstrate its reliability despite the existence of
a relevant ground for exclusion. If such documentation is considered as sufficient, the tenderer
concerned shall not be excluded from the procurement procedure.

its equity for the past financial year,

its assets for the past financial year,



question: Are there page or word limits for key sections of the bid?
answer:
Mentioned

The procurement documents specify a page limit for the descriptions of consultancy service agreements: each description must be provided in a separate document to the ESPD and **must not exceed two A4 pages**【ref_id:85】. No other explicit page or word limits for key sections of the bid are stated in the provided material.

question: How many copies of the bid need to be submitted?
answer:
Mentioned

The provided documents state that the tender must be submitted electronically via the Dalux Tender platform and that no other submission method is allowed [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:6](chunkref://6); they also describe the required content of the electronic tender [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:7](chunkref://7). However, none of the excerpts specify a required number of physical or electronic copies of the bid to be submitted. The only guidance given concerns the electronic nature of the submission, not a count of copies. Consequently, the exact number of copies required is not mentioned in the available context.

question: Are there any pre-bid meetings, and is attendance mandatory?
answer:
No mention  

The provided documents describe the pre‑qualification and tender management activities, such as responding to technical clarifications, reviewing applications, and “organising and leading site visits with the pre‑qualified tenderers” [App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:2](chunkref://9). However, there is no explicit reference to a pre‑bid meeting being scheduled, nor any statement that attendance at such a meeting would be mandatory. The sections on questions and answers, the electronic tendering system, and the overall procurement procedure also do not mention any required pre‑bid gatherings [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:6](chunkref://6);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:5](chunkref://5);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:4](chunkref://4). Consequently, the context does not contain information about pre‑bid meetings or attendance requirements.

2
General information
NunaGreen Construction Disco Bay A/S (“NunaGreen”) is tendering for a Consultancy Service
Agreement for the construction of a new hydroelectric power plant for the supply of Qasigiannguit
and Aasiaat, Greenland (“the Project”).

The Service Agreement includes consultancy services in connection with the Project. The
requirements for the services and contract terms are further detailed in the tender documents.

An overall description of the Project is to be found in the document ‘Scope of the Project’.

The Consultancy Service Agreement is based on FIDIC White Book.

3
Procurement procedure
3.1
Open procedure
The contracting entity will apply an open procurement procedure, which means that any
economic operator that fulfils the minimum requirements in the tender material can submit a
tender.

During the procurement procedure the contracting entity will ensure the equal treatment of all
tenderers. To that end, the contracting entity will: 
not provide information in a discriminatory manner which may give some participating
candidates an advantage over others,

inform all participating candidates in writing of any changes to the technical
specifications or other procurement documents.

question: Is there a clear timeline for the evaluation and award process? And who are the key decision-makers in the evaluation process?
answer:
Mentioned

The documents provide a general timetable for the procurement process (see the “Timetable” section) and specify that after the award decision is notified, a 10‑calendar‑day stand‑still period applies before a contract can be concluded [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:5](chunkref://5); [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:20](chunkref://20). However, they do not give a detailed schedule for the evaluation phase itself or the exact date when the award decision will be issued, so a precise timeline for the evaluation and award steps is not disclosed.

The evaluation and award are carried out by the “contracting entity”. The texts repeatedly state that the contracting entity will evaluate the qualitative criteria (organisation, qualifications, technical assistance) and will notify the award decision [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:18](chunkref://18); [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:20](chunkref://20). No individual names or specific decision‑making bodies within the contracting entity are identified, so the key decision‑makers are limited to the contracting entity as a whole.

question: Is there an appeal process if we are not selected? And will we receive feedback?
answer:
No mention

The provided documents describe the pre‑qualification process, the electronic tendering system, the timetable, the contents of the procurement documents, the procedure for submitting questions, the notification of award decision and the subsequent stand‑still period, as well as the scope of services for EPC contractor selection [App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:2](chunkref://8);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:6](chunkref://6);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:5](chunkref://5);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:2](chunkref://2);[Tender Conditions.pdf, p:20](chunkref://20);[App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:2](chunkref://9). None of these sections refer to an appeal mechanism for unsuccessful bidders or to the provision of feedback after the selection outcome. Consequently, the context does not contain any information about an appeal process or feedback provision.

question: Are there specific anti-corruption or ethical compliance requirements?
answer:
Mentioned  

The tender documents contain explicit anti‑corruption and ethical compliance obligations.  
- The Consultant is required to “abstain from all forms of corruption as set out in principle 10 of the UN Global Compact” [Client´s Code of Conduct.pdf, p:1](chunkref://3).  
- The Client also mandates that the Consultant comply with all applicable Greenlandic and Danish legislation, municipal regulations and guidelines concerning human rights, labour rights, the working environment, the environment and **business ethics** [Client´s Code of Conduct.pdf, p:1](chunkref://4).  

These clauses together constitute specific anti‑corruption and broader ethical compliance requirements for the contractor.

Requirements in relation to the legislation

question: What are the project objectives and deliverables? Write a brief summary (indicate: the location of the project and its specialness and potential difficulties, Does the project require innovative solutions? Does the scope require interdisciplinary expertise? Should the tenderer provide software, tools, or proprietary methodologies?).
answer:
Mentioned  

The project is the design, construction and commissioning of a new hydro‑electric power plant intended to supply electricity to the towns of Qasigiannguit and Aasiaat in Greenland [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:2](chunkref://2). Its specialness stems from the remote Arctic location and the technical complexity of hydropower works that may involve bored penstocks in lakes and tunnel works in rock, which require specialist knowledge and the ability to handle peak workloads [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:19](chunkref://19).  

Because of these characteristics the tender is expected to call for innovative engineering solutions (e.g., specialised penstock design, integration with grid and civil works) and to draw on a broad, interdisciplinary team. The required key personnel include a project manager, electrical, mechanical and civil design managers, a quality manager and an ICT manager, each with extensive experience in large‑scale hydropower or infrastructure projects [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:8](chunkref://8).  

The scope of services also includes tender management, technical clarification, site‑visit organisation, evaluation of bids, support for contract finalisation and preparation of award recommendations [App 1 - Scope of Services.pdf, p:2](chunkref://9). These tasks imply that the tenderer must deliver comprehensive documentation, project‑management outputs, design deliverables, quality‑assurance reports and ICT solutions for data management.  

The contracting entity will provide a Microsoft SharePoint platform for data storage and exchange and a Dalux Tender platform for the EPC pre‑qualification and tender process; the consultant is expected to use these tools but there is no explicit requirement to supply proprietary software or methodologies [App 2 - Personnel, Equipm.pdf, p:2](chunkref://5).

question: Does the project require full-time commitment from key experts?
answer:
No mention

The tender documents discuss the need to describe **how and how often** key personnel will be available to the contracting entity and stress that they should be **easily accessible** and that the core organisation should have a number of key personnel **adapted to the scope of services**【ref_id:91】. However, none of the provided excerpts state that the key experts must be engaged on a full‑time basis; they only require clarity on availability and accessibility, not a full‑time commitment.

question: Is the tenderer required to provide local staff? Or establish a local presence (office, legal entity)?
answer:
Mentioned

The provided documents do not contain any explicit requirement that the tenderer must employ local staff or establish a local office/legal entity in the project location. The sections describe the need to submit organisational charts, identify key personnel, and ensure those personnel are accessible to the contracting entity [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:19](chunkref://19); they also outline financial and technical eligibility criteria [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:10](chunkref://10); and they list procedural and documentation requirements [Tender Conditions.pdf, p:6](chunkref://6). However, none of these excerpts state a mandatory local presence or staffing obligation. Consequently, based on the available context, there is no mention of a requirement for local staff or a local legal entity.

question: Summary the payment terms (indicate: payment currency, is there any advance payments required, milestones and acceptance criteria, Does the contract allow for price adjustments if costs increase, any penalties for late delivery, is there any required local banking partner)?
answer:
Mentioned  

The contract specifies that all invoices must be issued in Danish kroner (DKK) and payments will be made in DKK to the Consultant’s designated account; any costs incurred in other currencies are to be converted to DKK using the official middle exchange rate published by the National Bank of Denmark on the date the expense was incurred [App 3 - Remuneration and Payment.pdf, p:2](chunkref://8).  

Payment is governed by the remuneration structure set out in Appendix 3, which distinguishes between fixed‑price services (paid according to an agreed payment schedule) and budget‑price services (paid on the basis of documented hours at the agreed rates). The schedule of payments for fixed‑price items is to be submitted with the tender, and hourly rates for additional or unforeseen tasks are also defined [App 3 - Remuneration and Payment.pdf, p:1](chunkref://2).  

The broader payment provision in the Consultancy Services Agreement states that the Client shall pay the amounts due under the Agreement in accordance with the provisions of Appendix 3 [Consultancy Services Agreement.pdf, p:3](chunkref://3).  

The provided documents do **not** contain any reference to advance payments, price adjustment mechanisms for increased costs, penalties for late delivery, or a requirement to use a local banking partner. Consequently, those aspects cannot be confirmed from the available context.

question: Summary the tax obligations and tax terms (indicate: who is responsible for local taxes?)
answer:
Mentioned  

The ESPD form requires the economic operator to confirm that it complies with its tax obligations in **both** the country where it is established and the Member State (or Greenland) of the contracting authority — i.e., it must pay all applicable taxes and social‑security contributions in those jurisdictions【ref_id:105】.  

The tenderer must be able to provide a certificate (or electronic evidence from a free‑of‑charge national database) proving that the taxes and social‑security contributions have been paid (or that a binding arrangement to pay them exists)【ref_id:97】.  

When the economic operator participates in a consortium or joint venture, **each** participating entity must submit its own ESPD form and certify its own tax compliance; the group as a whole is liable for the contract, but the responsibility for local taxes remains with each individual entity【ref_id:82】.  

If the operator has breached its tax obligations, it must disclose this in the exclusion‑grounds section; such a breach can lead to exclusion unless remedial measures are documented【ref_id:83】.  

Thus, the tax obligations fall on the economic operator (and on each consortium member individually) to ensure payment of local taxes and social‑security contributions in the relevant jurisdictions.
